questions.text: A middle-aged female presented with a chronic history of relapsing-remitting, mildly itchy, erythematous plaques over the scalp, sacral area, and knees with a history of joint pain nails as shown in the image. What is your most likely diagnosis? (SET - B) (DERMA)
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Psoriasis The given clinical scenario with chronic erythematous plaques and nails showing deep, coarse, irregular pitting is suggestive of Psoriasis which is a chronic T-cell mediated papulosquamous inflammatory skin disease.

Highyeild:

Psoriasis It is a chronic, T-cell mediated , inflammatory skin disease presenting with different phenotypes due to the interplay of genetics, environmental, and immunological factors. Normal epidermal transit time is 28 days. In Psoriasis, transit time is around 3 to 5 days leading to hyperproliferation of the Pathophysiology: T cell-mediated chronic infection. Association of gene PSORS1-9.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Lichen planus: Autoimmune disease with plain, purple, polygonal, pruritic papules. Mucosa shows a white lacy pattern. Nails have wing-shaped extensions of the proximal nail fold called pterygium. Option C. Adult onset still’s disease: It is characterized by intermittent high fever, and salmon-pink maculopapular rash which affects the proximal limbs and torso. Option D. Pachyonychia congenital: It is characterized by hypertrophic nail dystrophy, painful palmoplantar keratoderma and blistering, oral leukokeratosis, pilosebaceous cysts (including steatocystoma and vellus hair cysts), palmoplantar hyperhidrosis, and follicular keratoses on the trunk and extremities.

questions.text: A female with a history of Raynaud's Phenomenon, skin thickening, and breathlessness presents with skin lesions as shown in the image. Which of the following best represents it?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Salt and pepper Pigmentation The given clinical picture is showing Salt and pepper dyschromatopsia that is described as a vitiligo-like depigmentation with perifollicular pigmentary retention is a feature of It is a chronic multisystem disorder characterized clinically by thickening of the skin.

Highyeild:

Systemic sclerosis or Scleroderma It is a multisystem disorder characterized by Functional and structural abnormalities of blood vessels Fibrosis of the skin and internal organs Immune system activation Autoimmunity Age: 35 to 65 years, more in females than males Skin Manifestations of Scleroderma Raynaud's phenomenon (Most common and earliest symptom) Sclerodactyly and contractures in acral parts Mask-like features Beaking of nose Thinning of lips Radial furrowing around mouth Salt pepper dyschromatopsia Calcinosis cutis Periungual telangiectasia

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A . Leucotrichia: It is defined as the presence of a localized patch of white hair that can follow or precede depigmentation of the surrounding epidermis. It is caused by the loss of hair melanocytes found deep in the proximal anagen hair bulb. Option B. Vitiligo: It is an acquired, chronic, depigmenting dinsorder of the skin, in which melanocytes that determine the color of skin, hair, and eyes are progressively lost. It appears as milky-white patches of skin. Option C . Poikiloderma: It is a benign, common, and chronic condition, which belongs to the group of melanoderma. The term 'poikiloderma' refers to a skin change with atrophy where hypopigmentation/hyperpigmentation changes and telangiectasias can be seen in the affected skin.

questions.text: A patient presented to you in the OPD with a blackening of the palms after a recent episode of amebic dysentery for which he took medication. What can be the reason for such a condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Fixed drug eruption Skin manifestations due to a drug taken for amebic dysentery is most likely fixed drug eruption due to metronidazole..

Highyeild:

Fixed drug reaction It is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction (delayed type) Sites: Mucosa (most common) Trunk Extremities Drugs responsible: NSAIDS Cotrimoxazole Tetracyclines Carbamazepine Metronidazole Characteristics: Fixed location of drug reaction, due to memory-T cells formed after 1st exposure. On first-time intake, a reaction occurs after 10 days but with re-exposure, a reaction occurs within 30 mins to 8 hours of drug intake. The lesions are violaceous plaques with peripheral erythema Recurs at the same site Heels with hyperpigmentation Treatment: Stop the offending drug Topical corticosteroids

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Allergic contact dermatitis: It is a delayed hypersensitivity reaction to an allergen that comes into contact with the skin. It typically presents as an itchy, red rash with raised bumps or blisters that develop within 48 to 72 hours of exposure to the allergen. This condition is not associated with the blackening of the palms. Option: C. Maculopapular rash: It is a non-specific rash that can be caused by many different conditions, including viral infections, drug reactions, and autoimmune diseases. It presents as small, flat red bumps (macules) and raised red bumps (papules) on the skin. This condition is also not associated with the blackening of the palms. Option: D. Atopic dermatitis: It is also known as eczema, is a chronic inflammatory skin condition that causes itchy, red, and dry skin. It typically starts in childhood and is often associated with allergies and asthma. This condition is not associated with the blackening of the palms.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female patient presents with progressing skin lesions as shown in the image. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Basal cell carcinoma The given clinical scenario and the picture is of basal cell carcinoma . ' Basal cell carcinoma Most common skin cancer Found in sun-exposed part of the body: around upper lip Locally invasive, but rarely metastasize Features: Waxy, pink, pearly nodule that may start as small macula or papule Telangiectasias may be present Rolled out borders Central crusting and ulceration History of bleeding while itching may be present Histopathology: Basal cell tumors shows palisading nuclei. Treatment: Moh’s microscopic surgery Hedgehog pathway inhibitor: Vismodegib, Sonedigib

Highyeild:

Basal cell carcinoma is aka Rodent ulcer Common sites: Inner canthus of eye Outer canthus of eye Nose On and around nasolabial fold On the forehead

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Squamous cell carcinoma: Second most common skin cancer. It forms an indurated and ulcerated nodule located below the lower lip. Option C. Melasma: It is a common acquired skin disorder that presents as a bilateral, blotchy, brownish facial pigmentation. Option D. Discoid lupus erythematosus: DLE is a sub-type of chronic cutaneous lupus erythematosus. It is characterized by persistent scaly plaques on the scalp, face, and ears which subsequently can progress to scarring, atrophy, depigmentation, and permanent hair loss in affected hair-bearing areas.

Extraedge:

Risk factors for BCC: Sun exposure PUVA Surgical scar HPV infection Ionising radiation
